Ahmed ⁎ S.A. El-Hakam A.S. Khder W.S. Abo El-Yazeed Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Mansoura University, Mansoura, Egypt ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +20 502390551; fax: +20 502246104. Graphical abstract Highlights ► The SnO2 were impregnated with the appropriate amount of SO4 −2 solution to obtain, 5, 10, 15, 25 and 30wt% SO4 −2. ► The surface area values increase gradually with increasing SO4 −2. ► 25wt% SO4 −2/SnO2 calcined at different temperatures contains the strongest and the highest number of acid sites. ► The formation of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin increases gradually with increasing the amount of SO4 −2 loaded on SnO2. Nanocrystalline sulfated tin oxide with different sulfate contents (5–30wt%) were prepared from hydroxylated tin oxide obtained by the precipitation method, followed by wet impregnation with SO4 2− species using a sulfuric acid solution. In samples calcined at 400, 500 and 600°C the characterization of the solids was made by DTA, XRD and nitrogen adsorption. The strength and number of acid sites were determined by nonaqueous titration of n-butylamine in acetonitrile. Both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites were determined by FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorbed. Sulfated tin oxides were tested in the synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin via solvent free Pechmann reaction of resorcinol:ethylacetoacetate (molar ratio 1:2), at 120°C. DTA measurements showed that SO4 2− addition tends to slow down the formation of SnO2 crystallites. XRD profiles showed that the sulfating inhibits the SnO2 crystal growth. The SO4 species remained strongly bonded at the SnO2 surface stabilizing its crystallite size against sintering and it acts as a structure porogen director mediating nanoparticle growth and assembly yielding a mesostructured form of SnO2 with wormhole morphology and high thermal stability. The surface areas of the investigated samples were influenced with the sulphate content and calcination temperature. The acidity measurements showed that the total acidity increases with the rise of sulfate content up to 25wt%. FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorbed on the catalysts showed the presence of both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites. The formation of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin increases with the increase of surface acidity showing a maximum when the sulfate content and calcination temperature were 25wt% and 400°C, respectively. Keywords Sulfated tin oxide Calcination temperature Surface area Surface acidity 7-Hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin synthesis 1 Introduction Coumarins occupy an important place in the realm of natural products and synthetic organic chemistry. They have been used as anticoagulants [1], additives in food and cosmetics [2], and in the preparation of insecticides, optical brighteners [3], and dispersed fluorescent and laser dyes [4]. Coumarins have been synthesized by several methods including the von Pechmann reactions [5]. Conventionally, the Pechmann reaction is carried out in presence of concentrated sulfuric acid catalyst [6,7], phosphorous pentaoxide [8], trifluoroacetic acid [9] and aluminum chloride [10]. These acids are corrosive and required in excess amount. Homogeneous metal chlorides such as ZnCl4, TiCl4, InCl3, GaI3 [11–13], triflates [14], sulfonic acid [15] and ionic liquids [16] are reported to produce 7-hydroxy coumarin derivatives. To avoid such problems, there have been efforts to find environmentally benign alternative and heterogeneously catalyzed synthetic routes. This can be achieved by the development of solid acid catalysts that are stable, regenerable and active at moderate temperatures. Solid acids have emerged as potential alternate catalysts to homogeneous liquid acids [17,18] due to their non-hazardous nature, requirements in catalytic amounts, enhanced selectivity, the ease of separation without resulting into problem of waste disposal and easier post-reaction work-up. For the synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin only few studies are reported [19–22] using solid catalysts. It can be said that solid acids are the most important heterogeneous catalysts used today, considering in terms of both the total amounts used and the final economical impact. SO4 2−/M x O y is a new type of solid acid catalyst; it has some advantages such as it has good acid strength, it is quite stable to moisture, air and heat, is easily separated, less corrosive to reactors and containers, and more friendly to the environment [20]. These catalysts are finding numerous applications in oil refinery and petrochemical industries. Many studies have been reported concerning sulfated metal oxides as superacids, where sulfated zirconia (SO4 2−/ZrO2) and sulfated titania (SO4 2−/TiO2) which exhibits high catalytic activities for various reactions are typical examples [23–26], it shows strongest super acidity; its acid strength is lower than −16 on the Hammett function scale [27]. Commonly, the superacids have been prepared by following the next steps: (i) preparation of amorphous metal oxide gels as precursors; (ii) treatment of the gels with sulfate ion by exposure to a H2SO4 solution or by impregnation with (NH4)2SO4 and (iii) calcination of the sulfated materials at a high temperature in air. In this way sulfated tin oxide (SO4 2−/SnO2) is one of the most promising solid acids catalysis with strongest acidity. It has been reported that its acid strength can be comparable to that of SO4 2−/ZrO2 [28]. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of pyridine [29] and temperature-programmed reaction of adsorbed furan [30] indicate the possibility that SO4 2−/SnO2 has an acid strength higher than that of SO4 2−/ZrO2. Nevertheless, papers concerning the study of SO4 2−/SnO2 catalysts have been scarcely reported [31–33] because of the complexity in their preparation, in particular owing to the difficulty to obtain the oxide gels from its salts. Therefore, the study on SO4 2−/SnO2 superacid is benefiting both on the understanding of the essence of the solid super acid and on the acquaintance of more economic and it can be said that sulfated metal oxides are the most important environmentally friendly heterogeneous catalysts to substitute current liquid acids and halogen-based solid acids, with increasing emphasis on green chemistry [34]. However, to our knowledge the mesoporous SO4 2−/SnO2 has not yet been explored as a catalyst in Pechmann condensation reaction of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin. In this work, thermally stable mesostructured tin oxide was synthesized by functionalization of SnO2 nanoparticles obtained directly by precipitation of chloride precursor with ammonia, without surfactant, and sulfated with sulfuric acid. The SO4 2−/SnO2 catalysts showed activity during the Pechmann condensation reaction of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin at 120°C. Herein also, we aimed to study the effect of sulfate content and calcination temperature on the structural, acidic properties of the examined SO4 2−/SnO2 catalysts and the synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin from resorcinol and ethyl acetoacetate. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The oxide gel was prepared by the method described below. In a typical synthesis, 100g of SnCl2·2H2O (99% purity) were dissolved in 500ml of distilled water with vigorous stirring and heating with adding few drops of concentrated HNO3, then at 30°C aqueous solution was added dropwise a NH4OH (25vol%) solution with continuous vigorous stirring until the solution reach a final pH 8. The pale yellow gel type precipitate obtained was filtered and suspended in a 4% CH3COONH4 solution during 30min. Then, the Sn(OH)2·xH2O gels were impregnated with the appropriate amount of a 1M H2SO4 solution to obtain 5, 10, 15, 25, and 30wt% of sulfate. After, the gels were dried at 110°C for 24h and calcined at 400, 500 and 600°C for 3h. In the designation of these samples, the roman numbers I, II and III refers to the calcination temperatures. The designation 5S-Sn-III indicates the sample containing 5wt% SO4 2− and calcined at 600°C. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 Thermal analysis Thermal analysis (DTA) of the uncalcined samples was carried out using a Shimadzu thermal analyzer, type 50-H. The samples under examination were heated in N2 stream at a rate of 10°C/min. 2.2.2 XRD investigation The powder diffraction patterns were recorded on X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD) PW 150 (Philips) using Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.540Å) at 40kV, 30mA and a scanning range 2Θ of 18°–60°. The crystallite size (nm) was calculated from the broadening of the strongest peak of SnO2, peak (110) at 2Θ =26.6°, using Debye–Scherrer equation [35]: D = k λ β cos Θ where k is the crystallite shape constant (≈1), λ is the radiation wavelength (Å), β is the line breadth (radians) and Θ is the Bragg angle. 2.2.3 Surface area measurement The specific surface areas of the calcined samples were determined from nitrogen adsorption studied conducted at −196°C using the high vacuum conventional volumetric glass system. Prior to any adsorption measurement the sample was degassed at 250°C for 4h under a reduced pressure of 10−5 Torr. 2.2.4 Surface acidity measurements 2.2.4.1 Potentiometric titration The total acidity of the solid samples was measured by means of potentiometric titration [36,37]. The solid (0.05g) was suspended in 10ml acetonitrile (Merck), and agitated for 3h. Then, the suspension was titrated with 0.025N n-butylamine in acetonitrile at 0.005ml/min. The electrode potential variation was measured with an Orion 420 digital A model using a double junction electrode. 2.2.4.2 Pyridine adsorption Lewis and Bronsted acid sites presented on the surface were determined with FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine. Prior to the pyridine adsorption [38], the samples were degassed at 200°C for 3h under high vacuum and then the samples were cooled to 30°C. The dry pyridine was then flashed inside the vacuum system and the samples were maintained under these conditions for one month. Then, the excess pyridine was removed by evaporation. The FT-IR spectra of the samples were conducted using MATTSON 5000 FTIR spectrophotometer; by mixing 0.005g of the sample with 0.1g KBr in 30mm diameter self supporting discs were used. 2.2.5 Catalytic activity The synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin was carried out by using resorcinol (10mmol) and ethylacetoacetate (20mmol) with 0.1g of the activated catalyst (at 120°C for 2h). The reaction was carried out in oil bath at 120°C under stirring and reflux for 2h. After the reaction, the product was separated by transferring the hot reaction mixture in ice bath and stirring for about 15min, then filtration. The product was collected by filtration and re-crystallized using ethanol. Finally the product was characterized by GC–MS, 1H NMR analysis and melting point measurement. The % yield of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin was calculated by different methods [39–41] one of them is as follows [39]: Yield ( wt % ) = Obtained weight of product Theoretical weight of product × 100 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Thermal analysis (DTA) The DTA curve of the Sn(OH)4 shows four-steps decomposition behavior: three endothermic and two exothermic decomposition processes (Fig. 1 ). The first endothermic process occurring from room temperature to 115.1°C is attributed to a loss of physically adsorbed water. The second endothermic process is abroad one from 180.4 to 380.1°C, such high temperature dehydration step was ascribed to the dehydration and dehydroxylation of amorphous tin hydroxide. The removal of water from the hydrous tin oxide is the rate-limiting step in crystallization of amorphous tin oxide [42]. The thermogram of Sn(OH)4 showed that there is an exothermic effect at around 450°C which is attributed to the combustion of acetate ions used in the washing solution in the preparation step [42]. After dehydration, the hydrous tin oxide is progressively decomposed into tin oxide due to dehydroxylation with increasing temperature and a sharp exothermic peak appears around 600.1°C. This exothermic is assigned to a rapid release of bound hydroxyl groups at a higher temperature, by which tin oxide is suddenly formed and crystallized into essentially pure SnO2 [43]. This exothermic peak was shifted to higher temperature as sulfate content increased, reaching 626.3 and 637.2°C for 25 and 30wt% SO4 2−/Sn(OH)4 samples, respectively. This means that, the interaction of surface sulfate with tin oxyhydroxide stabilizes its SnO2 structure and shifts its crystallization to higher temperatures [43,44]. For 25wt% SO4 2−/Sn(OH)4, there is an endothermic peak located at 323.5°C which is divided into two endothermic peaks at 297.4 and 322.2°C, this may be attributed to the overlapped process of bond fission of Sn–sulfate groups and the removal of acetate ions used in the washing solution [45]. 3.2 X-ray diffraction analysis The effect of sulfate content on the crystallinity of SO4 2−/SnO2 is shown in Fig. 2 . The stabilization of crystallite size by the SO4 groups bonded to the SnO2 surface can be clearly observed by comparing the XRD patterns of the sulfated tin oxide calcined at 600°C and without sulfate. XRD, Fig. 2A, of pure tin oxide shows the characteristic patterns of pure SnO2 phase with tetragonal cassiterite structure at 2θ =26.7°, 33.8°, 37.9° and 51.7° and they are the diffractions of (110), (101), (200) and (211), of tetragonal SnO2 [46], respectively. The tetragonal cassiterite phase was also showed by the sulfated tin oxides; however the intensity of the bands gradually decreases. SnO2 phase existed as nanocrystalline phase measuring a crystallite size of about 27.7nm which has a moderate degree of ordering or crystallinity. On the other hand, XRD patterns in Fig. 2B and C show the possible crystallization process of SnO2 on increasing the SO4 2− content for 5S-Sn-III, 15S-Sn-III and 30S-Sn-III samples and the calcination of 25S-Sn sample at 400, 500, and 600°C. All samples were found to display four well-distinguished peaks at 2θ =26.6°, 33.8°, 37.9° and 51.7° corresponding to characteristic tetragonal cassiterite phase structure of SnO2. The presence of SO4 2− and the increase in calcination temperature stabilizes the tetragonal phase of SnO2, and such stabilization of tetragonal SnO2 in the presence of SO4 2− and other oxides has been reported in the literature [47,48]. The addition of SO4 2− into tin oxide significantly influenced the crystallinity of SnO2. Fig. 2C suggested a decrease of crystallinity in the SO4 2−–Sn nanoparticles in comparison with the unloaded sample by the decrease in the intensity of SnO2 peaks. This means that a portion of SO4 2− formed could occupy regular lattice site in SnO2 and that may cause the introduction of point defects and change in stoichiometric due to charge imbalance. The effect leads to a distortion of the crystal structure of the host compound and the crystallinity of the SO4 2− loaded SnO2 nanoparticles was worse than that of pure SnO2. The rise of calcination temperature for 25S-Sn sample, Fig. 2B was associated with narrowing of the XRD lines, indicating the beginning of the removal of SO4 2− groups bounded to SnO2 phase and suggesting the sintering of crystalline SnO2. The crystallite size diameter (D) of the SnO2 nanoparticles has been calculated by Debye–Scherrer equation [35] at 2θ =26.6°. Examination of Fig. 3 A shows that the crystallite size of pure SnO2 started at 27.7nm, addition of sulfate was associated with a notable decrease of crystallite size to reach 8.1nm for 25wt% SO4 2−/SnO2 then increases to reach 9.3nm at 30wt%. The decrease in the crystallite size can be explained by the hypothesis that the bulky sulfate groups on the surface of SnO2 particles prevent their agglomeration during calcination [49], while the increase in the crystallite size of 30wt% SO4 2−/SnO2 over that of 25wt% SO4 2−/SnO2 may be due to the presence of an excess amount of SO4 2− on the surface of SnO2 catalyst. Gutiérrez-Baez [50] by XRD Rietveld analysis found that crystallite size increased considerable when the SO4 groups were removed from SnO2 surface. It can be also seen from Fig. 3B that the crystallite size increases gradually by increasing the calcination temperature from 400° to 600°C. A small narrowing of the SnO2 lines as function of the temperature can be observed showing a small increase of the crystallite size [51]. Recently, Toledo-Antonio et al. [52] had reported that in sulfated tin oxide the hydroxyls remaining in the bulk of the crystallite generate a structure poorly crystallized with a large amount of tin vacancy sites. This small sintering of crystalline SnO2, can be attributed to the loss of some sulfate groups bonded to SnO2. In the sulfated samples, the amount of SO4 2− required for stabilizing the SnO2 structure depends on the amount of hydroxyls remaining in the starting nonsulfated sample. When the samples are calcined at 400°C, most of OH− groups are eliminated and the SO4 2− groups remain strongly bonded at the SnO2 surface. The fresh sulfated SnO2 sample, which has SO4 2− and also hydroxyls in it, presented a large amount of tin vacancy sites which decreased while calcining the sample at 500°C. However, when SO4 2− was eliminated when the calcination temperature increases the tin vacancy sites decreases and thus the crystallite size increases. 3.3 Surface area The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, Fig. 4 , showed the type II isotherms in the IUPAC classifications [53], with a H3 type hysteresis loop, which is characteristic of the presence of a large proportion of mesopores [54]. The isotherms of these catalysts have a closed hysteresis loops and desorption branches joints the adsorption ones at relative pressure of about 0.35–0.50. The BET surface area of SnO2 crystallites was found to be controlled by adjusting the calcination temperature and the sulfate content. As it is clear from Table 1 , the surface area values increase gradually with increasing SO4 2− loading to reach a maximum limit at 25S-Sn, then decrease. Pure tin oxide calcined at 400°C showed a surface area of 41.6m2/g, addition of SO4 2− to SnO2 results in an increase in the surface area from 45.0 to 150.8m2/g for 25S-Sn-I. The main explanation relies on the replace of the hydroxyl groups present on the surface by sulfate ions resulting in more rigid and stable 2D-surface SO4 2− layer which impedes the crystallization of SnO2 as evident from X-ray diffraction measurements, and decreases the mobility of defects on the grain surface and surface energy of the support metal oxide grain [55,56]. 2D-surface SO4 2− layer is believed to contribute to thermal stabilization by increasing of the Sn–O–Sn separation as reported by Norman et al. [57] for sulfated zirconia. When the calcination temperature was increased from 400 to 600°C, the surface area values moved to lower relative value with the consequent increase in the corresponding pore diameter, Table 1. The above results suggest that the interaction between SO4 2− and SnO2 crystallites not only stabilizes the crystallites in lower dimensions, but it remains at the SnO2 surface inhibiting the crystallite aggregation and acts as a structure progeny director mediating nanoparticles growth and assembly. Also the sulfate groups remain bonded to the surface, stabilizing the mesotructure walls with pore diameter values changed from 3.1 to 16.9, Table 1. The changes in surface area and pore diameter were due to the structural transition from a wormhole mesotructure to a nanocrystalline material which had interparticle mesoporosity. Fig. 5 B represents the change in the surface area with the calcination temperature for 5S-Sn, 15S-Sn, 25S-Sn and 30S-Sn calcined at 400, 500 and 600°C. The loss of surface area with further increases in calcination temperature above 400°C, possibly due to multilayer formation, bulk properties of SO4 2− will be more predominant, causing crystallites, as was partially proved by XRD. It is not surprising to find that, both crystallite size values (Fig. 3A and B) and specific area values (Fig. 5A and B) vary with opposite manner when changing the sulfate content and calcination temperatures. XRD analysis is in line with the surface area results, confirming that, the addition of sulfate impedes the crystallization of SnO2 [39,58] and leads to notable increase in its surface area up to 25wt% SO4 2−. Pore diameter values, Table 1 also decrease with sulfate content up to 25wt% SO4 2− and then increases. Calcination temperatures are accompanied with an increase in the pore diameter. These observations also support the change in surface area values. 3.4 Characterization of SO4 2−/SnO2 by FT-IR spectroscopy FT-IR spectra of 25S-Sn-I, Fig. 6 exhibits absorption bands at 1246, 1137, 1069 and 1048cm−1, which are characteristic of inorganic chelating bidentate sulfate and are assigned to a symmetric stretching frequencies of partially ionized SO double bonds and SO bonds [59]. The presence of Bronsted acid sites is proved by this ionic structure [60]. The band at 989cm−1, was assigned to the interaction of sulfuric group with dehydrated SnO2 [61] indicates more complex structures, possibly at different crystallographic surface, or (SO4 2−)ad species. These results can be explained in terms of surface heterogeneity of the sulfated samples; leading to sulfate groups of slightly different spectroscopic signatures, from isolated ones to polynuclear ones [59]. 3.5 Surface acidity of the investigated catalysts 3.5.1 Nonaqueous titration The surface acidity of the investigated catalysts was determined by nonaqueous titration of n-butylamine (pK a =10.73), which is a basic molecule suitable for titrating the medium and strong acid sites on the surface of the investigated catalysts [62,63]. The trend of the titration curves, Fig. 7 is asymptotic, leading to a characteristic value on the potential axis, which in turn is related to the volume added of n-butylamine/g needed for neutralization of the surface acidity [64]. The end point of the titration given by the inflexion point of the curve is a good measure to carry out a comparison of the acidity of the different samples. The initial electrode potential (E i ) indicates the maximum acid strength of the sites [65]. The total surface acidity and the maximum acid strength are listed in Table 1. It was suggested that the initial electrode potential (E i ) indicates the maximum acid strength of the sites. On the other hand, the acid strength of these sites may be classified according to the following scale [62,63]: E i >100mV (very strong sites), 0< E i <100mV (strong sites), −100< E i <0 (weak sites) and E i <−100mV (very weak sites). Table 1 show that the number of acid sites of sulfated tin oxide samples is higher than that of pure tin oxide by a factor of 2.3–9.5 times. Addition of sulfate was accompanied by gradual increase of both number and strength of acid sites to reach maximum at 25S-Sn-I (Table 1) at which E i =592mV. More over the samples calcined at 400°C showed the highest acidity and relatively higher acidic strength, which may be due to strong interactions between sulfates and SnO2 surface. Further increase in calcination temperature up to 500°C and 600°C was accompanied notable decrease in the acid strength. It is evident from Table 1 that the total acidity of the samples increases with the increase in sulfate content up to 25wt% and calcination temperature up to 400°C, where the maximum total acidity. Further increase in sulfate content or calcination temperature leads to decrease in the total number of acid sites/g (Table 1). This means that, the distribution and number of sulfate groups on the surface of SnO2 is responsible for the higher acidity at 400°C, thus the heating of SO4 2−/SnO2 (OH)2(H2O) x at this temperature can be described as: SO4 2−/SnO2 (OH)2(H2O) x →(SO4 2−)−SnO2 +(xH)H2O 3.5.2 FTIR spectra of chemisorbed pyridine The infrared spectra in the spectral region 1560–1440cm−1 of adsorbed pyridine on the different samples (Sn, 5S-Sn, 15TPA-Sn, 25S-Sn and 30S-Sn) calcined at 400°C are shown in Fig. 8 . All the samples show typical bands of adsorbed pyridine at around 1484, 1535cm−1 on Lewis and Bronsted acid sites, respectively [66–69]. Although there is a band at 1506cm−1 which may be due to Lewis and Bronsted acid sites together. The bands located at around 1535cm−1 are due to pyridinium ion (PyH+) reflecting its interaction with Bronsted acid sites. The bands at 1484cm−1 are characteristic for coordinative bonded pyridine on electron acceptor sites (Lewis center). One can clearly see the bands at 1484 and 1536cm−1 ascribed to Lewis and Bronsted acidity centers; where the intensity of these bands depends on the chemical composition of the catalyst. The percentage of Lewis–Bronsted acid sites can be calculated by using the integrated areas or the relative intensity of the characteristic bands of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis and/or Bronsted acid sites [70,71]. Other authors determine the concentrations of Bronsted and Lewis acid sites [72,73] from the integral intensity of the corresponding bands in the IR spectra and the values of the molar extinction coefficients as 1.67 and 2.22cm/μmol for Bronsted and Lewis acid sites respectively. Thus % Bronsted=(A B/A B + A L)×100 and % Lewis=((A L/A B + A L)×100, where A B is the integrated area of the peak at 1535cm−1, attributed to the pyridinium cation adsorbed on the Bronsted acid site and A L is the intensity at 1484cm−1 of the pyridine molecule coordinated to the Lewis acid site. The number of Bronsted and Lewis acid sites as a function of sulfate content and calcination temperatures is presented in Table 1 and Fig. 9 A and B. It was found that with an increase in SO4 2− loading; Lewis and Bronsted acidities were increased reached the maximum at 25S-Sn loading. The increase of Lewis acidity by sulfate species may be due to the presence of surface sulfur complex which has a covalent SO bond, that acts as electron-withdrawing species followed by the inductive effect. Thus, the inductive effect of SO makes the Lewis acid strength of Sn4+ stronger [74] as illustrated by the model in Scheme 1B . The number of Lewis acid sites decreases gradually with increasing the calcination temperature while Bronsted sites drop sharply with calcination temperature as evident from Fig. 10 for 25S-Sn sample calcined at 400, 500 and 600°C. This may be due to the removal of sulfates bounded to SnO2 surface as the calcination temperature increases. In comparison the acidity determined from both methods, it was found that the same trend of arrangement of catalysts acidity, but the difference is that the electrode potential measures the total acidity and the acid strength as reported early by Dominguez et al. [75], while the pyridine adsorption differentiate between the two types of acid sites. The Bronsted/Lewis acid site ratios Table 1 increase with an increase of the inserted amount of sulfate up to 25wt% and calcination temperature of 400°C and then decreased. It seems that the increase of the overall amount of sulfate leads to complex polynuclear sulfates that could exhibit a strong effect of acidity enhancement surface Bronsted acid sites and thus B/L acid site. This confirms that the coordinated surface sulfate groups create the strong acidity 25S-Sn contains the strongest and the highest number of acid sites; this may be attributed to the generation of more Bronsted acid sites. It is expected that the initial decomposition of SnO2−x (OH) x (HSO4) x −(nH2O)(YC2H3O2)→SnO2−x (OH) x (HSO4) x + nH2O+YC2H3O2 during the thermal treatment in air at low temperature may proceed to give acetate and water. Adsorbed water may then react with the adjacent sulfate groups to yield adsorbed bisulfate (HSO4 −) and hydroxyl groups. In a similar manner to that [50] at low sulfate concentration, the surface presumably is rich with the hydroxyl and bridging hydroxyl groups along with bisulfate groups. Upon heating to higher temperature, the bisulfate undergoes a kind of condensation reaction with the adjacent hydroxyl groups to evolve water and forms bridging bidentate sulfate group on the surface with the formation of weak and strong Lewis acid sites, Scheme 1A and B. Scheme 1A and B presents a schematic diagram of the proposed low and high sulfate load surface structures with showing both, the Bronsted and Lewis acid sites. The decrease in the surface acidity and acid strength for 30S-Sn may be due to the agglomeration of sulfate species on the SnO2 surface. 3.6 Catalytic activity 3.6.1 Synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin We found that SO4 −2/SnO2 could be used for condensation reaction of resorcinol with ethyl acetoacetate without using any solvent. A background reaction was examined with resorcinol and ethyl acetoacetate in the absence of SO4 −2/SnO2 and no product was observed. Here we have successfully used solid acid catalysts as an alternative to conventional methods for synthesis of coumarins. 3.6.2 Effect mole ratio Initially, the liquid phase Pechmann condensation of resorcinol and ethylacetoacetate to 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin was performed at 120°C for 2h using 25S-Sn catalyst with varying ratio of substrate (resorcinol:EAA, 1:1 to 1:3), Fig. 11 . From Fig. 11, it has been observed that the percentage yield of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin increases from 78.3% and 81.1% to 95.8% with the increase in the molar ratio of resorcinol:ethylacetoacetate from 1:1 and 1:1.5 to 1:2 respectively with 100% selectivity. A further increase in resorcinol:ethylacetoacetate molar ratio to 1:3 was accompanied by a decrease in the percentage yield of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin to 76.8. The ratio of resorcinol:EAA, 1:2, was found to be optimum for the solvent free synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin. Similar result was reported by Marosi et al. [76] and Palaniapp and Shekhar [77]. 3.6.3 Effect mole ratio 12 The effect of reaction time on the formation of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin was carried out by varying the reaction time between 30 and 180min at a mole ratio of 1:2 using 0.1g of 25S-Sn catalyst calcined at 400°C and the maximum yield (95.8%) was obtained around 2h. The percentage conversion is fast and after 2h constant increase in the formation of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin is observed. The initially rate of desorption of the product from the catalyst surface is high and as concentration of the product increases in the reaction mixture the rate become very slow or reach to constant value. The optimum conditions for this condensation reaction are temperature 120°C, reactant mole ratio 1:2 and reaction time 2h to get maximum yield (95.8%) using 25S-Sn-I as solid acid catalyst. Several studies have been carried out to study the effect of solid acid catalysts on 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin synthesis, however, with different observations. For example, Wang et al. [14] found the yield of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin using Yb(OTf)3 (95%). Hoefnagel et al. [78] have reported the yield of the same derivative using zeolite and amberlyst (80%). Romanelli et al. [79] also found similar yield of the same derivative using heteropoly acid catalyst (87%). From these studies, it seems that the efficiency of the catalyst may be depend upon the amount and the strength of the acid sites on the catalysts used and seems to be responsible for the variation in the yield of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin. 3.6.4 Effect of SO4 2− content and calcination temperature on the catalytic activity Table 1 shows the catalytic properties of catalyst S-Sn for Pechmann reaction of resorcinol with ethylacetoacetate. In Table 1, the formation of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin increases gradually with increasing the amount of SO4 2− loaded on SnO2 till reach the maximum at 25wt% SO4 2− calcined at 400°C. In this case, the specific surface area is increased till reach the maximum at 25wt% SO4 2− calcined at 400°C, thus the attached-on-surface sulfate groups are increased both the intensity and in number of acid sites. On increasing the calcination temperatures for 25S-Sn, the 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin yield decreases, Fig. 12 . This may be due to the decrease in the catalysts acidity and number of Bronsted acid sites as a result of the loss of sulfate species bounded to SnO2 surface. When the temperature continues to rise, the crystallization tends to be completed and the sulfate groups begin to decompose, yielding both decrease in the S BET and surface acidity and number of Bronsted acid sites. This is in accordance with the XRD and DTA results. The literatures [80,81] report the influence of sulfate on SO4 2−/M x O y , showing the introduction of appropriate amount of sulfate would stabilize the surface sulfur-containing species; increase the acidity of the catalyst and also the catalytic activity in the reaction. Two mechanistic pathways [82,83] have been proposed for the Pechmann condensation reaction for the synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin. The first one [82], is based on proton transfer to a keto group of ethylacetoacetate from Bronsted acid sites of the catalyst by interaction of ethylacetoacetate with catalyst followed by the nucleophilic attack of the hydroxyl group of resorcinol, resulting in an intermediate and ethanol. The intermediate rapidly undergoes cyclization through acid catalyzed intra-molecular condensation yielding 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin. The second possible mechanism is reported by Selvakumar et al. [83] and based on reaction catalyzed by acid sites of the catalysts, i.e., electrophilic reaction of chemisorbed ethyl acetoacetate on resorcinol wherein chromones is produced as side product. In the present reaction, we have not observed the formation of chromones during reaction, so the mechanism proposed by Selvakumar et al. [83] was ruled out. Based on the above discussion, a probable mechanism for the formation of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin using synthesized nanosize S-Sn was presented in Scheme 2 . 3.6.5 Reusability of catalyst 15 Recycling of the catalyst is an important aspect of any industrial process. For this purpose, reusability of the catalyst is tested by carrying out a repeated runs of the reaction at 120°C, keeping the reactants molar ratio of resorcinol:EAA at 1:2. After performing the reaction over fresh catalyst, the catalyst was washed with hexane and acetone and then was dried at 120°C for 4h the reaction was again performed on the reactivated catalyst. It is evident that the activity of the catalyst did not decrease appreciably even after three cycles as shown in Fig. 13 for 25S-Sn-I. The 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin formation was of 95.8%, 88.6%, and 78.2% in the fresh and used catalysts. Hence, the decrease in the conversion can be ascribed to the decrease in the SO4 2− content in solid catalyst due to partial leaching of the SO4 2− as confirmed by FTIR (Fig. 6) in which the sulfate groups are present but some leaching occurs as evident from the decrease in IR intensity of these groups. 4 Conclusions In this work, nanosized SnO2 particle with crystal size of 27.7nm was prepared by chemical precipitation method using ammonium hydroxide and tin tetrachloride. The as-prepared powders and the samples soaked in the sulfate solution were calcined at 400, 500 and 600°C. DTA, XRD, N2 adsorption at −196°C, the potentiometric titration with n-butylamine and FTIR were used for the characterization of the prepared catalysts. The stabilization of crystallite size by the SO4 groups bonded to the SnO2 surface was clearly observed. The sulfate groups increase the specific surface area, stabilizing the mesostructured walls and increasing its thermal stability. There is a direct correlation between catalytic activity and acidity holds for synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin. Catalyst activity also indicates that the activity for synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin is related to the availability of Bronsted acid sites originated from SO4 2− groups which in turn depends of the SO4 2− content and calcination temperature. Sulfated tin oxides are solids acids catalysts of low pollutant and promise catalysts in the production of alternative. References [1] L.A. Singer N.P. Kong J. Am. Chem. Soc. 88 1966 5213 [2] O. coredata.dc:description: Nanocrystalline sulfated tin oxide with different sulfate contents (5–30wt%) were prepared from hydroxylated tin oxide obtained by the precipitation method, followed by wet impregnation with SO4 2− species using a sulfuric acid solution. In samples calcined at 400, 500 and 600°C the characterization of the solids was made by DTA, XRD and nitrogen adsorption. The strength and number of acid sites were determined by nonaqueous titration of n-butylamine in acetonitrile. Both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites were determined by FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorbed. Sulfated tin oxides were tested in the synthesis of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin via solvent free Pechmann reaction of resorcinol:ethylacetoacetate (molar ratio 1:2), at 120°C. DTA measurements showed that SO4 2− addition tends to slow down the formation of SnO2 crystallites. XRD profiles showed that the sulfating inhibits the SnO2 crystal growth. The SO4 species remained strongly bonded at the SnO2 surface stabilizing its crystallite size against sintering and it acts as a structure porogen director mediating nanoparticle growth and assembly yielding a mesostructured form of SnO2 with wormhole morphology and high thermal stability. The surface areas of the investigated samples were influenced with the sulphate content and calcination temperature. The acidity measurements showed that the total acidity increases with the rise of sulfate content up to 25wt%. FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorbed on the catalysts showed the presence of both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites. The formation of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin increases with the increase of surface acidity showing a maximum when the sulfate content and calcination temperature were 25wt% and 400°C, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Nanostructure sulfated tin oxide as an efficient catalyst for the preparation of 7-hydroxy-4-methyl coumarin by Pechmann condensation reaction
